YMedia.use("media-preview-default",function(Y){
          
    Y.later(10, this, function() {(function(){ var rapid = YMedia.rapid; if (rapid) { rapid.addModules("mediacontentrelatedstory"); } }());
    });
});
});
        
        </script></head>

    <header class="header">
            <h1 class="headline">President Obama to order more training, oversight for military gear to cops</h1>
            <h2 class="subheadline">Will fund 50,000 body cameras for police officers.</h2>
    </header>

        <div class="Grid-U Pstart-8 pl-info">
            <p class="pl-title LineClamp Fz-s Mt-0 Mb-2">

U.S. Close to Deal With Turkey Over Islamic State Mission: WSJ</p>
            
                
            
            <p class="Dn pl-desc">The United States and Turkey are closing in on a deal that will allow the U.S. military and allied forces to use Turkish air bases in their campaign against Islamic State militants in Syria, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.
The newspaper, citing U.S. and Turkish officials, said the agreement could include a safe zone along a portion of the Syrian border to protect refugees and certain opposition forces that would also &amp;quot;be off-limits&amp;quot; to aircraft from Syrian President Bashar al-Assad&amp;#39;s government.
Allowing the United States and its allies to use Turkey&amp;#39;s bases would allow the coalition forces another foothold from which to launch continued strikes against the militants.</p>
        </div>
    </a>
</li>

<li class="Grid Trigger Pos-r Py-4 pl-item" data-uuid="5425f14a-ab01-34c9-bdfd-87761158ee1c" data-idx="8">
    <a href="https://screen.yahoo.com/news-videotron-new/us-attorney-general-addresses-ferguson-033352332.html" class="rapidnofollow" data-ylk="cat:News Videotron;g:5425f14a-ab01-34c9-bdfd-87761158ee1c;pkgt:1;pub:60033121-000d-3d16-b182-83f6ba351995;sec:News Videotron;cpos:8;bpos:1;" data-alias="us-attorney-general-addresses-ferguson-033352332" title="US Attorney General Addresses Ferguson Forum in Atlanta" data-rapid_p="24">
        <div class="Grid-U Wpx-24 Va-m Fz-xs Ta-c pl-order">
            <p class="playlist-order">9</p>
            <i class="Icon Fz-3xs C-1"></i>
        </div>
        <div class="Grid-U-1-3 Va-m Pos-r pl-img">
                
                    <img src="http://l.yimg.com/os/mit/ape/m/81f43c2/t.gif" class="W-100 ImageLoader ImageLoader-Delayed" alt="US Attorney General Addresses Ferguson Forum in Atlanta" style="background-image:url('http://l3.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/RTZ6IY6mRRUDxgK33yEx3w--/dz0yMDg7Zmk9ZmlsbDtweW9mZj0wO2g9MTE3O2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/http://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/video/video.storyful.com/92bc31039deb0f1564c84cf339ff2f97')">
                
                
                    
                        <p class="Fz-xs duration Pos-a B-0 End-0 Py-2 Px-4 M-0">0:45 </p>
                    
                
                <span class="current pl-marker Pos-a T-0 B-0 Start-0 End-0 C-1 Fz-xs Py-4 Px-6 smooth Tt-u Ta-c">Now watching</span>
                <span class="next pl-marker Pos-a C-1 Fz-2xs Py-4 Px-6 smooth Tt-u">Up next</span>
        </div>
        <div class="Grid-U Pstart-8 pl-info">
            <p class="pl-title LineClamp Fz-s Mt-0 Mb-2">

US Attorney General Addresses Ferguson Forum in Atlanta</p>
            
                
            
            <p class="Dn pl-desc">US Attorney General Eric Holder announced on Monday, December 1, that the Justice Department will set out new guidelines to limit racial profiling by federal law enforcement.The meeting took place at Atlanta’s Ebenezer Baptist Church, where Holder led a community discussion following nationwide protests over a grand jury decision to not indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer that fatally shot unarmed, black teenager Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri.
&lt;a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/01/eric-holder-ferguson-michael-brown_n_6251628.html" target="_blank"&gt;International media&lt;/a&gt; reported that Holder described the problems triggered by the Ferguson case as &amp;quot; truly national in scope&amp;quot; and said the nation “needs to confront the broken relationship between many law enforcement agencies and the communities that they are supposed to serve.”
His speech was interrupted by protesters yelling flash mob, saying, “It is our duty to fight for our freedom.” A &lt;a href="https://twitter.com/ReporterBlayne/status/539595539940388865" target="_blank"&gt;journalist&lt;/a&gt; reported that the crowd responded with cheers.
This video shows part of Holder’s speech on December 1.
The full transcript of the speech is &lt;a href="http://www.justice.gov/opa/speech/attorney-general-eric-holder-delivers-remarks-during-interfaith-service-and-community" target="_blank"&gt;available here&lt;/a&gt;. Credit: Facebook/William G. McCray III</p>
        </div>
    </a>
</li>

<li class="Grid Trigger Pos-r Py-4 pl-item" data-uuid="fb9ff43f-78dd-35bf-a324-1958f0c63c90" data-idx="9">

Atlanta’s Ebenezer Baptist Church, where Holder led a community discussion following nationwide protests over a grand jury decision to not indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer that fatally shot unarmed, black teenager Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri.\n<a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/01/eric-holder-ferguson-michael-brown_n_6251628.html\" broken relationship between many law enforcement agencies and the communities that they are supposed to serve.”\nHis speech was interrupted by protesters yelling flash mob, saying, “It is our duty to fight for our freedom.” A <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ReporterBlayne/status/539595539940388865\" target=\"_blank\">journalist</a> reported that the crowd responded with cheers.\nThis video shows         <meta itemprop="description" content="President Barack Obama is expected to sign an executive order to encourage more oversight of federal programs that dole out military gear to local police departments, senior administration officials said Monday.">
        <p>President Barack Obama is expected to sign an executive order to encourage more oversight of federal programs that dole out military gear to local police departments, senior administration officials said Monday.</p><div class="body-slot-mod"><div class="yom-remote"><div class="" id="mediacontentrelatedstory_container"> <section class="yom-mod " id="mediacontentrelatedstory" data-ylk="mid:mediacontentrelatedstory;mpos:1;elm:hdln;elmt:ct;cat:Related Stories;rspns:nav;t1:a3;t2:lst-ct;itc:0;sec:lst-ct;"> <div class="yom-related-story-module story sidekick "> <div class="hd"> data-ylk="itc:0;tar:news.yahoo.com;ct:1;sec:lst-ct;cpos:1;test:312063;g:465146de-d392-39fe-bc94-1ae730d70d1b;pkgt:2;prov:Associated Press;" data-rapid_p="1">Obama: Wants to avoid 'militarized' police culture</a> <span class="source">Associated Press</span> </li>  <li class="list-item story" data-uuid="d5a70c01-db4f-3ecf-b393-3e6660205ab7"> <a href="/obama-hold-meetings-monday-ferguson-004348391--politics.html" data-ylk="itc:0;tar:news.yahoo.com;ct:1;sec:lst-ct;cpos:2;test:312063;g:d5a70c01-db4f-3ecf-b393-3e6660205ab7;pkgt:2;prov:Associated Press;" data-rapid_p="2">Obama to hold meetings Monday on Ferguson</a> <span class="source">Associated Press</span> </li>  <li class="list-item story" data-uuid="416d1512-c8cf-3299-9b32-02a151b98a3d"> <a href="http://www.vox.com/2014/12/1/7314603/body-cameras-police" data-ylk="itc:0;tar:www.vox.com;ct:1;sec:lst-ct;cpos:3;test:312063;g:416d1512-c8cf-3299-9b32-02a151b98a3d;pkgt:2;prov:Vox.com;" data-rapid_p="3">Obama wants to put body cameras on 50,000 more cops</a> <span class="source">Vox.com</span> </li>  <li class="list-item story" data-uuid="d0bcd53d-dcd4-3f67-9d6b-c1ffe9f5e20d"> <a href="/obama-vows-address-simmering-distrust-between-police-minorities-022049666.html" data-ylk="itc:0;tar:news.yahoo.com;ct:1;sec:lst-ct;cpos:4;test:312063;g:d0bcd53d-dcd4-3f67-9d6b-c1ffe9f5e20d;pkgt:2;prov:Reuters;" data-rapid_p="4">Obama vows to address 'simmering distrust' between police, minorities</a> <span class="source">Reuters</span> </li>  <li class="list-item story" data-uuid="b3758368-4d0f-3f0c-8c79-ca997904f30b"> <a href="/obama-move-police-body-cameras-ferguson-unrest-020914898.html" data-ylk="itc:0;tar:news.yahoo.com;ct:1;sec:lst-ct;cpos:5;test:312063;g:b3758368-4d0f-3f0c-8c79-ca997904f30b;pkgt:2;prov:AFP;" data-rapid_p="5">Obama to move on police body cameras after Ferguson unrest</a> <span class="source">AFP</span> </li>   </ol> </div> </div> </div> </section>

</div></div></div><p>The executive order will direct agencies that distribute military-style equipment to local police to require training for cops that receive the gear. The president will also require officials to create a central database to track the supplies, as a <a href="http://news.yahoo.com/how-does-a-police-department-lose-a-humvee-025942542.html" data-rapid_p="27">significant number of weapons and vehicles previously allocated have gone missing</a>. But the review also stressed that the programs provided "valuable" assistance to police departments and stopped short of criticizing the gear as promoting "militarization" of police.</p><p>Obama ordered a review of Pentagon, Justice Department and Homeland Security programs that arm local police after a military-style response to protests in Ferguson, Missouri prompted outrage in August.&nbsp;</p><p>Local officers showed up to control protests sparked by the fatal police shooting of unarmed teen Michael Brown in armored tank-like vehicles, wearing military-style riot gear, and holding assault weapons. Police were also photographed aiming the weapons at protesters, in contravention of military procedure, sparking criticism that they had not been adequately trained.&nbsp;Police said they needed the gear to protect themselves.</p><p>“There is a big difference between our military and our local law enforcement, and we don't want those lines blurred,” Obama said at the time.</p><p>But it's unclear if the president's actions will have any effect on the amount of military-style gear the federal government doles out to local cops.</p><div class="body-related">
    <a href="/photos/fatal-shooting-of-teenager-sparks-protests-slideshow/" class="body-related-link body-related-slideshow go-to-slideshow-lightbox rapid-noclick-resp landscape onesize " data-list-id="dd7b1aa0-2081-11e4-9efb-a5208b00726c" data-type="slideshow" data-pos="1" data-ylk="t1:a3;t2:ct-mod;t3:embd;sec:ct-mod;slk:expand;elm:img;elmt:ct;itc:1;g:0724e367-3a4b-3efb-9dac-8a364c05cbdc;aid:dd7b1aa0-2081-11e4-9efb-a5208b00726c;ct:4;cpos:1;" title="Fatal shooting of teenager sparks protests in Ferguson,&amp;nbsp;&amp;hellip;" data-rapid_p="28">
        <div class="img-wrap">
                <div class="cta-overlay">
                    <span class="clearfix title cta-text medium"></span>
                    <span class="cta-text xsmall  ">View gallery</span>
                    
                    <span class="icon-slideshow icon-white-slideshow-xsmall "></span>
                    
                </div>
            <img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/q40QXvVtFFLe0ayPkPSoug--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3M7Zmk9ZmlsbDtoPTIwOTtxPTc1O3c9MzAw/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/ap_webfeeds/b01bd2d1650020205d0f6a7067005a17.jpg" width="300" height="209" class="body-related-thumb" alt="Fatal shooting of teenager sparks protests in Ferguson,&amp;nbsp;&amp;hellip;" data-src-2x="">        </div>
    </a>
        <div class="body-related-title photo-caption" style="width: 300px">Protesters run when the police shoot tear gas in Ferguson, Mo., Sunday, Aug. 17, 2014. Protests over&nbsp;…</div>
</div><p>On a call with reporters, administration officials would not say whether the president supports or opposes bipartisan efforts in Congress to ban local police departments from receiving recycled armored vehicles from the war in Afghanistan and certain kinds of assault rifles.</p><p>The president’s planned executive action also does not appear to immediately affect the 460,000 weapons and other controlled pieces of military equipment that have already been doled out from the Pentagon to local law enforcement agencies, including more than 5,000 Humvees and 92,000 guns.</p><p>Obama does plan to dole out one new piece of equipment to police departments that will likely please civil liberterians: The White House will allocate $75 million dollars over three years to provide police departments with up to 50,000 body-worn cameras for their officers.</p><p id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_1572">Civil rights advocates have long pushed for all police officers to wear the cameras, to prevent against excessive use of force against civilians. Brown's parents announced a campaign to equip officers with cameras.</p><p id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_862">Press Secretary Josh Earnest said the administration sees "some benefits" to the cameras, but that they're not a silver bullet. "<span id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_1570">I don't think there's anybody who thinks that that's going to solve every single problem or that that's going to address every issue related to mistrust that might exist between some communities and their local law enforcement officials," Earnest said.</span></p><ul id="topics" class="hidden"><li data-id="YCT:001000661">Politics &amp; Government</li><li data-id="YCT:001000681">Government</li><li data-id="WIKIID:Barack_Obama">President Barack Obama</li><li data-id="WIKIID:Police">police departments</li><li data-id="WIKIID:Executive_order">executive order</li><li data-id="WIKIID:Military_technology">military equipment</li></ul>
        <!-- google_ad_section_end -->
    </div>
</div>

</section>

                <div class="nickname" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_1599">

                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">5</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_1603">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    All this does is to make the police officer an easier target. The Criminals have the weapons they obtain from the military black market, Uzis and AK's and M16's. what are the police suppose to do, turn their back when they see a black doing something wrong, Just because he is black. I am getting the feeling that it might be better for the black community to police itself. They don't want to follow any rules of conduct or community talks unless they are about what "they" want, not about how the people should follow the police commands or conduct themselves in a manner as not to invite the police to act as police. But What do I know, I went through the race riots, the black panthers farce and the I am black and better then you attitude, for the last 30-40 years, It an't got no better. I will say this though, the hate for toward whites from blacks of the lower class has gotten worst. There is an almost palatable feeling of anger when going in an area of many blacks or mostly black community This feeling is starting to move out to the urban areas of cities. Has any one else felt it or am I just feeling something that isn't really there?

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Where were the Civil Rights Advocates????<br>
<br>
“Channon Gail Christian, 21, and Hugh Christopher Newsom, Jr., 23, were a couple from Knoxville, Tennessee. They were raped, tortured, and murdered after being kidnapped. Christian’s vehicle had been carjacked. Five suspects were arrested and charged in the case. The grand jury indicted four of the suspects on counts of capital murder, robbery, kidnapping, rape, and theft, while a fifth was indicted at the federal level. Of the four charged at the state level, three (Letalvis D. Cobbins, Lemaricus Davidson, and George Thomas) had multiple prior felony convictions. After a jury trial, Lemaricus Davidson was sentenced to death by lethal injection and Letalvis Cobbins and George Thomas were sentenced to life in prison, Cobbins without the possibility of parole and Thomas with the possibility. Vanessa Coleman has been convicted of facilitating the crimes and sentenced to 53 years in prison, and Eric Dewayne Boyd has been convicted of federal charges as accessory after the fact to carjacking and sentenced to 18 years in prison…”<br>
<br>
“Christian and Newsom were leaving an apartment together to go to a friend’s party when they were abducted from the apartment complex parking lot. Christian’s parents found her abandoned Toyota 4-Runner two blocks away from the Chipman Street house the following Monday with the help of her mobile phone provider. An envelope recovered from the vehicle yielded fingerprint evidence that led police to Lemaricus Davidson and 2316 Chipman Street. When police went to the address on Tuesday, January 9, they found the house unoccupied and Christian’s body in a bin in the kitchen.<br>
<br>
According to the testimony of the Knox County Acting Medical Examiner Dr. Darinka Mileusnic-Polchan at the subsequent trial of Eric Boyd, Newsom was repeatedly sodomized with an object and then blindfolded, gagged, arms and feet bound and his head covered. Barefoot, he was dragged outside the house to a set of nearby railroad tracks. He was sexually mutilated, shot in the back of his head, neck and back and his body was then set on fire.<br>
<br>
According to the testimony of the medical examiner, Channon’s death came after hours of torture, having suffered injuries to her #$%$, #$%$ and mouth. She was raped with an unidentified object and beaten in the head. It was also reported that her body was scrubbed with bleach which was also poured down her throat, in an attempt by her attackers to remove DNA evidence, while Channon was still alive. She was then bound with curtains and strips of bedding, her face covered with a bin liner and her body stashed within five large bin bags, before being placed inside a residential waste disposal unit and covered with sheets. The medical examiner said there was evidence that Channon slowly suffocated to death.<br>
<br>
Where is the outrage? Where is the weeks of violent protest? Where is the disruption of public events?

                    A great deal of the military surplus equipment that is here in Florida are old style, Helos, APC's, Small Arms and a whole bunch of uniforms.<br>
In 37 of the lower 48 states, there are/is more surplus military heavy weapons like tanks, APC's, 6x6 trucks, jeeps,humvee's<br>
and tons of small arms all bought by the resident public and until recently very available.<br>
If the public wants to see some of this stuff, search the WEB for machine gun shoots like the one near Ft.Knox,KY.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Hey, here's a concept. Don't commit crimes and you won't place yourself in negative situations. (If any of the taxpayer dollars are going to be spent on cameras it should be for those of you with previous arrest records to wear body cameras that stream the footage to law enforcement. If at any time the cameras are removed or tampered with, police will be notified. That way everyone around you will be held accountable as well and last week's verdict would have been made without question). Let me repeat this message: Do not commit crimes.<br>
Michael Brown's proven previous arrest record (you can look all of this up yourself on Case.net Missouri. Do a search for St. Louis County in 2014; you'll find Michael Brown):<br>
<br>
Description: Burglary 1st Degree [Felony B RSMo: 569.160] <br>
<br>
Date: 11/02/2013 Code: 1401000<br>
OCN: AJ006207 Arresting Agency: ST ANN PD <br>

Next Charge/Judgment <br>
<br>
Description: Armed Criminal Action [Felony Unclassified RSMo: 571.015]<br>
Date: 11/02/2013 Code: 3101000<br>
OCN: AJ006207 Arresting Agency: ST ANN PD <br>

Description: Assault 1st Degree Serious Physical Injury [Felony A RSMo: 565.050]<br>
Date: 11/02/2013 Code: 1301100<br>
OCN: AJ006207 Arresting Agency: ST ANN PD <br>
<br>
Next Charge/Judgment <br>
<br>
Description: Armed Criminal Action [Felony Unclassified RSMo: 571.015]<br>
Date: 11/02/2013 Code: 3101000<br>
OCN: AJ006207 Arresting Agency: ST. ANN PD <br>
<br>
Now, I know that robbing convenience stores and then going into police cars to get an officer's gun may add to all of this fun, but you see, it may lead to negative consequences. And I know that in a perfect world some of you may wish for white police officers to back up and drive the other direction whenever they see a black man committing a crime or surrender peacefully whenever a black man enters their squad car and tries to take their gun away from them, but one of the main duties of police officers is to protect (especially their own lives). Refraining from committing crimes may be a new concept but you should really give it a try sometime. And by the way, be careful what you wish upon white police officers. You just might need one some day.<br>
<br>
The preceding has been a public service announcement from those with common sense.

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Executive Order -- National Defense Resources Preparedness signed by Obama. March 2012.<br>
<br>
Not only says he can call for Martial Law, but takeover the following.<br>
<br>
 (1)  the Secretary of Agriculture with respect to food resources, food resource facilities, livestock resources, veterinary resources, plant health resources, and the domestic distribution of farm equipment and commercial fertilizer;<br>
<br>
(2)  the Secretary of Energy with respect to all forms of energy;<br>
<br>
(3)  the Secretary of Health and Human Services with respect to health resources;<br>
<br>
(4)  the Secretary of Transportation with respect to all forms of civil transportation;<br>
<br>
(5)  the Secretary of Defense with respect to water resources; and<br>
<br>
(6)  the Secretary of Commerce with respect to all other materials, services, and facilities, including construction materials.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_2164">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Obama's Vision for America:<br>
<br>
"Two 'unaccompanied minors' carjack elderly veteran in Iowa"<br>
Examiner: October 9, 2014 10:29 PM MST	<br>
<br>
"On Wednesday, police arrested two Guatemalan nationals, ages 16 and 17, following a high speed chase which ended on Interstate 80, just outside Iowa City.<br>
<br>
Around 6 a.m., the pair walked out of Maryville Academy in Des Plaines, Ill., and committed their first carjacking of the day. They then drove 165 miles to a Walmart in Moline, Iowa, where they ordered a 91-year-old man out of his car, according to police.<br>
<br>
Moline Police Det. Scott Williams stated: "They obviously chose him to take his vehicle. He walked with a cane. They watched him go in and get his medication from the VA."<br>
<br>
The illegal aliens smashed into a car on the way out of the parking lot, driving another 220 miles in the stolen vehicle, until so-called 'stop sticks' were thrown in their path by Iowa state troopers. Their actions were captured on store surveillance video.<br>
<br>
The two suspects came to the U.S. in the recent surge of illegal aliens flooding across our border from Central America and Mexico.<br>
<br>
The teens had been transferred to the Illinois facility after crossing the US-Mexico border as unaccompanied minors and requesting asylum in the United States.<br>
<br>
Maryville Academy is a residential facility for at-risk and mentally-ill youths. The U.S. Health and Human Services agency has sent a number of so-called "unaccompanied minors" to the facility in the last several months.<br>
<br>
Though U.S. Border Patrol agents have reported that many of the more than 60,000 minors who have come to this country illegally over the last several months, are gang members, Obama administration policy demands that they be allowed to enter. Many of these teens have been identified as members of the hyper-violent Latin American gang known as MS-13."<br>
<br>
<br>
Fact: The Democrat controlled Senate refused to vote on the House Republicans' Immigration Bill! Democrats knew criminals with diseases were crossing our open borders but still released 350,000 from prison and shipped them to our neighborhoods to harm those who protect us and ENFORCE OUR LAWS.
                    </p>

And BTW, if they know a lot has already gone missing, don't shrug it off - damn well find the thieves and lock them up (with a jar of KY Jelly).
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    I think body cameras are a good thing, they will bring more accountability to police and it is a way of increasing the public trust as well as decreasing complaints against the police. I am a 2nd amendment lover, fisher, hunter, boater, camper, and am all for police using outdated or recycled military equipment.                 <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_2594">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Look I don't like Obama but I will tell you why some of this is good. Studies have shown that Police Departments whose officers wore body cameras had decreased complaints. In fact, one PD in Minnesota had as many as 90% less complaints after the fact. Furthermore, police should be held to the same standard we all are held to. In my state, an officer was at a bar on the job, hit and killed someone, fled the scene, and all charges were dropped. I respect cops, and like what they do, my cousin is in the academy right now. But I think they should have some more accountability. Most cops are good its only the bad ones you hear about. By the way, I love guns and the 2nd ammendment, I have no issues with police using recycled military gear, and I believe the young generation should be taught how to respect police and respect each other to make America a better place.
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                        In a city near where I live, the illegals literally took over the area. If the fire department showed up, they would steal and vandalize the equipment. It got so bad the city said no fire or rescue could enter this area until enough police were on hand to protect the other services. After a few lives were lost, the other folks who lived there said enough is enough, and pulled together and had the city pass laws and ordanances to rid these rodents. Less than 3 years later the community is flourishing and becoming a great place to live.

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    WOW! Obama is late to the party, this has been an issue for years! Did you know that many small police departments have received weapons and guns because some one higher up got greedy at these bargain bin prices and ordered too many!<br>
<br>
My issue with this is that while a soldier can do some policing work, he or she is trained to take out the perceived enemy, far from home.<br>
<br>
Police are trained to uphold the law and keep people safe, use non lethal weapons and deterrents on our own populace and escalate up to the full use of lethal force only as a last possible effort.<br>
<br>
Soldering, away from home, lethal vs., Policing, at home, non lethal preferred.<br>
<br>
Now you give some great and fun weapons to folks with out the training and they kill and maim. Wow, surprise! That pregnant lady who lost an eye because some Barney Fife got to use a sandbag non-lethal shotgun load to her face from 3 feet away kind of proves the point.<br>
<br>
Why do we cycle out our armory? Because those Humvees are old, those MRAPs have had it with the mines and IEDs, Those active duty armaments need to be used to replace the National Guards equipment that has been used up.<br>
<br>
We are a war machine nation, but are we so stupid to go to war with ourselves? You want to win war on the road and never play at home!<br>
<br>
Was a soldier, now in law enforcement, we don't need or want all of this stuff. SWAT? sure load them up as they desire it. Bomb techs get whatever they put on their wish list because we appreciate what they do.  <br>
<br>
Do you have any idea how much diesel it takes to top off a fleet of these toys? Do you want to have to pass additional levees to pay for the maintenance and upkeep? Do you know the cost of pulling the pack and replacing parts? You can't afford it.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                        Opinions are often paraded as facts by those wishing to promulgate a point with no basis in actual fact or statistical authority.<br>
<br>
STATISTICS: Noun - the science that deals with the collection, classification, analysis, and interpretation of numerical facts or data, and that, by use of mathematical theories of probability, imposes order and regularity on aggregates of more or less disparate elements.(Websters)<br>
<br>
To answer earlier assertions that’s statistics are not facts, you are correct, they merely organize them, they do no not create them. <br>
However, to imply that statistics are made up to serve a specific viewpoint ignores the reality that the data so classified is obtained from numerous unaligned and unconected sources. How one choses to interpret or otherwise use statistics in presenting or supporting any contention is another matter – that is the political spin which should always be questioned.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>
            </div>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3158">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Friend Of Obama And Founder Of Largest Gay Rights Org Charged As Pedophile<br>
Terry Bean, 66, co-founder of the Human Rights Campaign and the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, has been arrested on sodomy and sex abuse charges that allegedly involved a 15-year-old Oregon boy.<br>
<br>
Also charged is Bean's former boyfriend, 25-year-old Kiah Lawson. The two are said to have set up the meeting with the child through the gay dating app, Grindr. The incident happened in a Eugene, OR hotel in September of 2013.<br>
<br>
Bean pleaded not guilty and posted bail. He will appear in court in December. His lawyers say these allegations are a larger part of an extortion ring against the gay rights activist.<br>
<br>
The ex-boyfriend also pleaded not guilty. Lawson's mother, Tim Nouanemany, told local KOIN 6 News that Bean "groomed" her son with "alcohol and Viagra" in order to "get [Bean] young kids." She says her son went from "a happy young man" to "someone who is not himself" after meeting Bean.<br>
<br>
Lawson helped police with the investigation by providing the phone number of the teen, but that also lead to his arrest. Lawson charged that Bean had installed a hidden camera above his bed to capture sexual encounters.<br>
<br>
Bean is a prominent Democrat, a member-at-large of the Democratic National Committee and ardent supporter of Barack Obama, Al Gore, and Bill Clinton. Bean contributed $500,000 to Obama's reelection campaign in 2012. At many events, including one hosted by HRC, Obama thanked his "good friend" Bean. CNN has a detailed report of this relationship with video.<br>
<br>
Bean's lawyer declares, "Terry Bean is a highly respected community leader who has devoted his life to bettering our community. No allegations against [him] should be taken at face value. We look forward to the opportunity to clear his name.”
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3527">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Law enforcement is just that.   Equal force to subdue criminal activity is becoming impossible.   Superior force and occasional examples of such need to happen to bring peace to the community.   If an officer abuses his or her badge, and commits a murder without justification, then it is necessary to bring criminal charges.   <br>
Criminals are people who break the law, not bend it.  Jay walking is not criminal.  Throwing rocks at police is.  <br>
Peaceful protest is a great way to make a point and gain support.  Having a mass tantrum, and burning down a neighborhood, because a select group of people want to see the lawless idea supported by courts, is criminal.   Be realistic and be respectful, don't steal, don't rob, don't commit battery.   When a cop tells you to do something, do it.   If he is in the wrong, report it later.
                    </p>

        <div class="comment-container clearfix   " id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3679">
        <div class="actions">
                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="Don" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3678">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="4MKNBVORFLRCAAJOQYK5NXEEFU">Don</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">8 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">2</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">13</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3677">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    The use of military equipment and tactics also fits into the common practice of favoring ex-military or military police as candidates for law enforcement. Since they use a military structure and chain of command they prefer those who are already familiar with the routines. Also, they tend to bypass civilians with higher education/intelligence because they tend to get bored with mundane police activities and might question policies that seem dysfunctional. Gearing up to fight criminal enterprises like drug dealing cartels is one thing but using similar techniques against average citizens will only widen the gulf between law enforcement and the general public. When people begin to see law enforcement as the "enemy" or at least the "bad" guy something needs to be done. There was a time when police were more active and present in the community and interacted regularly with the public but budget constraints have changed that to an "as needed" response plan.  In too many cases the police respond only when summoned but when the public refuses to pay for more and better officers they have little choice.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>
                <div class="action-container clearfix" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_3683">

                    Little Johnnie's mother was black and his father was Jewish.  Little Johnnie came home from school one day and ask his mother if he were more black or more Jew. His father asked what on earth made him ask  a question like that.  Little Johnnie said, "Well Freddie is selling his bike and he wants $50. for it.  I don't know whether to try to Jew him down or just wait till it gets dark and steal it.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_4322">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    I know good whites.  I know good black folks too.<br>
<br>
Like the rest of you, I've also witnessed my fair share of trash. and there's plenty of it, both black and white.  <br>
<br>
It's all about how you're raised, your surroundings, the company you keep.  What has the biggest impact on a youth?  Poverty, low income, fractured families, no accountability, poor parenting, no jobs.<br>
<br>
Ferguson didn't come into existence overnight.  It likely was a good town, good middle class people.  There most likely was industry there.  Jobs.  Income for doing an honest days work.  A stable job = a better chance at a stable home, a stable life.  <br>
<br>
The real question is.....       what was Ferguson like 10, 20, 30 and 40 years ago?  What really happened.<br>
<br>
I still think the officer was right to defend himself.  My rant isn't about Wilson and Brown.  <br>
<br>
This is about the ENTIRE community of Ferguson, but not just Ferguson.  It's about similar communities where there is no hope.<br>
<br>
Believe me, there are many.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_4553">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                        You have no idea what you are talking about.  A police agency is a paramilitary organization that  puts itself between the public and the bad guys.  Equipment given to police agencies allows them to equip themselves with equipment that small agencies could not afford.  I retired from an agency with about 1,000 officers but that included corrections personnel.  It was a huge benefit for our officers to be equipped with personnel carriers, aircraft and other means of protection.  Your sentences do not make sense.  I don't remember where a law enforcement was militarized by the federal government.  Law enforcement agencies sometimes have a state agreement that they can be deputized to travel to other agencies any where in the state to assist with any type of problems.  As far at training, you and Obama have no idea what kind of training agencies are required by state laws to put their officers through.  Many agencies have officers trained by DHS in case of terrorism.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_4518">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    We can't train.  Our budget is too diminished at this point.  The National Guard had to cancel TWO training months in August and September due to a budget shortfall and the lodging program has been canceled entirely.  Our Soldiers aren't even eating hot meals any longer, it's all MREs now because the food budget was slashed as well.<br>
<br>
Do you want to discuss training?  We can't train in the field because we can't afford to supply our new Soldiers with proper training equipment.  We can't fire our weapons because we can't afford ammunition.  We can't afford to drive to the training centers because our fuel bills were too high.... We can't afford to repair our vehicles because of the cost but we don't have anyone to repair them because the mechanics were all terminated.<br>
<br>
We can't train.
                    </p>

As far as the Ferguson riots go, there is this pesky little document that you imbeciles keep forgetting.  It is called the Constitution and according to the Bill of Rights Amendment 10, also known as State's rights, he can not interfere unless specifically asked to.  The Ferguson situation is a "murder" vs "self Defense" issue which is NOT covered int he Constitution.  There are NO murder clauses in the Constitution, therefore this becomes a state ISSUE!  <br>
<br>
Former President Bush did the same thing when Katrina hit and everyone knocked him for it.  Until the state asks for help, he can not do anything!  He can voice his opinion and make a public announcement asking the American people to "calm" down, but until the State asks for help from the National Guard, his hands are tied, unless he feels the states are not doing their job and the federal government needs to take over through the National Security clause.  Which he really does not want to do because then that would claim the Governor is incompetent, which would lead to people like you saying he "over stepped his bounds " again.  <br>
<br>
With you people he is dammed if he does and dammed if he doesn't.<br>
<br>
<br>
"This is in contrast to his immediate reaction to the arrest of his Boston friend who disturbed the peace, calling one of the two policemen the white, racist, the other is black;"<br>
<br>
Citation needed.<br>
<br>
"And it is in contrast to his immediate reaction to Tayvon Martin's death, "If I had a son, it would be like him. "<br>
<br>
Citation needed.<br>
<br>
<br>
"It appears, therefore, Mr. Obama"s point of view, the convenience store robber-er could well be an Obama. The riot makers may well be his brothers and sisters."<br>
<br>
Another statement by an imbecile.  <br>
<br>
<br>
"The policemen who work to maintain the order during the riot are racists if white from Mr. Obama's stand point."<br>
<br>
Citation needed.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_4876">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    This was a real conundrum for Obama. At least with the Trayvon Martin case, the two people involved were both civilians. That made it easy for Obama  to side with the black youth, and make comments like, " If I had a son, he'd look just like Trayvon".  But the Brown case involved a black civilian and a white  police officer. The police officer is a public servant, and so is Obama, representing the same Constitution and the same country. So Obama said nothing. He never spoke to the Mayor of Ferguson, even to ask if there was something he could do to help. He never spoke to the Police Chief. He only spoke to Sharpton, and the other riot organizers, and told them to, "Keep pushing".<br>
   I can't imagine a more divisive person in the Oval Office.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5083">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    During the current fiscal year, DHS plans to award $1.6bn in grant money for state, local and tribal agencies, mostly to aid them with counterterrorism, border security and disaster preparedness, it announced last month. By contrast, the Defense Department’s “1033” program to transfer surplus military gear gave out less than $500m worth of equipment in fiscal 2013.<br>
<br>
Two grant programs in particular, awarded through the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema), provide the lion’s share of the DHS money: the State Homeland Security Program and the Urban Areas Security Initiative.<br>
Obama was behind and pushing for local police departments getting military equipment. part of his " civil military" he talked about. now all of a sudden he claims to be against it? because of what happened at ferguson? or is it because many local police forces have stated they will not be part of any gun confiscation programs ?

        <div class="comment-container clearfix   " id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5337">
        <div class="actions">
                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="Controversial Truth" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5336">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="4PS35KQIVGA5OHYEYD6I42SLDY">Controversial Truth</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">7 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">2</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">0</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5335">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    If you only read one comment, read this one. It's long but it's worth it, money back guarantee.<br>
<br>
One day I went to a gas station and purchased a mountain dew and powerbar to snack on. I leave the gas station and make a right turn and now I'm in the right lane. Then I was going to make a left turn but I stay in the right lane because I don't change lanes without purpose. I make a left turn from the right lane into a dead end corridor. There was no one around me when I made the left turn, which is why I didn't use the center lane to turn. I hate people, so that's why I wanted to park in the area, so I could eat a snack in peace. I'm very familiar with the area, no one is over here on the weekends. I circle around and look for shade. I find shade and I back up, then I realize I'm not completely in the shade, so I pull forward and back up again to get into the shade more. I put the car in park and turn off the vehicle and reach for my snack. All of a sudden in the corner of my left eye, I see a cop car coming and for a second I'm thinking he's just driving by, but instead he stops his car right in front of my car. He jumps out of his car and says Let me see your hands. I stick my hands out my window. He approaches me. He looks like this guy : Thomas Burke Pulver ktla, that's not the guy, it's just to give you a better visual, it could be his brother. He had sunglasses on. He asked me why people were calling and saying I'm running red lights, he says they got my license plate number. I remained silent with a slight smile on my face as I was puzzled. He told me he saw me make a left turn without using the center turn lane and without using my signal. I simply said that's just how I drive. He never asks me to elaborate that any further. He asks if I've ever been arrested, I said a cop took me to a hospital because I wouldn't speak. And he said "So you were 5150." And I said "Something like that." He asks me where I live, I say 30 miles away. He asks "what are you doing here?", I said I'm just parked I'm having a snack. I lift up said snack to show him. And he said "You came all the way over here to have a snack?" I just remain silent as I look around trying to figure out what's going on. Then he says "You were trying to run away and you ended up in a dead end street so you tried to hide over here and act like you weren't trying to run away and then you pulled forward to see if I was gone and you saw me coming so you backed up again." And I said I didn't see you until your car was right in front of me. He never asks me to explain why I pulled forward and backed up again.<br>
<br>
 He tells me to take off my sunglasses, which funny enough were the same pair he was wearing. Maybe he thought my glasses were recording him. I comply. He tells me to put my head back and close my eyes and stick out my tongue. And he starts to say that I'm on drugs. He asks if he can search my car. I ask if I can refuse, and he says "Yes, but I'll take you down to the station just to prove a point to you". Another cop shows up and he goes and whispers to the cop and he comes back over again and tells me again to stick out my tongue and put my head back, then the other cop says uh oh, and plays along with the other cop. So they tell me to get out of my car and he searches my pockets, finds nothing. Tells me to go sit on the front of the cop car. The second cop asks "Why are people saying you're running red lights?", Then I say anyone can say that about anybody. And he said "Just like anyone can see you're on drugs right now?" I just look away while shaking my head in disbelief. The first cop comes over, he ask me some more questions. He says there's a lot of mountain dew in the car, so maybe that's why you're driving the way you are, because you have a small wee wee because you drink too much mountain dew. I just remain silent. Then again he asks me why people were calling and saying I was running red lights and driving reckless, I say reckless is a point of view sir. The two cops look at each other for a second, then the first cop leans down and tells me to put my hands behind my back, I comply, then he says it again, trying to make the other officer think I'm resisting arrest, because the other officer was behind me, so he couldn't see that my hands were already behind me the first time he asked. He handcuffs me, extra tight, then he says to the other cop "I'm gonna have a workout today huh" He asks me if there's anything valuable I want to take out of the car, and I say everything's valuable sir. And then he says is there anything you can carry on yourself that you want to take. And again I just say everything's valuable sir. The other cop puts me in the cop car and fastens my seatbelt while the first cop starts searching my car, even though I still have not given permission. The cop searches the car, he gets to the back seat and, uh oh, he finds a gun ... he calls back his partner to show him why he chose to search my car without my consent ... but then after further examination, they determine it's just a BB gun, so the cop is looking pretty stupid right now. He searches some more and finds nothing. He comes back and asks me why I didn't want him to search, I said because it's a waste of time sir, then he said "but you knew I was going to search it anyways right ? " Then I said I'm not a psychic sir. Then he says "you are just high as a kite aren't you". I just look at him like what the hell ? He brings me my wallet and cash he found in the car, even though I didn't ask for it. I guess he was trying to play "good cop bad cop" with me so that I don't file a complaint. <br>
<br>
 On the drive to the station, he says " I'm new here, I normally don't arrest people for a little bit of drugs." I remain silent, then he continues to talk and says "So you run red lights, that's scary huh?". And I said I'm the best driver in the world. And he says "Better than me, with all my training?" And I said yes. And he said "What makes you the best driver?" And I said you see this red light in front of us, after this car turns we can go thru the red light. And he says no you can't, and I said not legally. And he said "Yeah you could probably make it, and cops are allowed to run red lights, and one time I ran a red light and I nearly killed the motorcyclist that I hit." Then I said "So you didn't make sure it was clear before you went through the red light?" And he said "Man you are just high as a kite aren't you." And I said "So the stupid rule the world?" And he said "Well, you aren't ruling anything right now."<br>
<br>
 While at the station, he takes me into a dark room to do an eye pupil test. He tells me to close my eyes to allow them to adjust to the lighting. He then says "My hands are gonna be right by your face so don't freak out." He was just trying to sound legit for the audio recordings in case I file a complaint about him. He'll just say I was acting "jumpy" and that's why he thought I was on drugs, wink wink. What I find interesting though is that the SAME cop who arrests you for DUI is the SAME cop who does the eye exams at the station, so he could easily fake the report to make his claims seem more legit. Anyways, we leave the room, a female officer searches me again, and as she was reaching around from behind, the cop who originally arrested me was looking at me with his mouth open, as if he was watching a porno or something. I just ignored him and I just kept asking questions about random stuff. They moved me to another room. I kept asking random questions trying to get them angry. The cop kept using usual cop clichés. He randomly says "My paycheck is the same whether I arrest you or not." Then the female officer was asking me more questions about where I work / live. Then she asks my eye color and I just stare at her. She asked me again, and I just keep staring at her. She then says "whatever". And I say "You can't see my eyes from 3 feet away?" Then she says "Well the cop wrote down they were hazel." And I'm just thinking to myself what the hell does that matter. Perhaps that was her "Good cop bad cop" moment, trying to compliment my cute eyes or something. Anyways I keep exercising my free speech at the station and asking questions and the female officer said I was being uncooperative, so then I say to her "Exercising my freedom of speech is being uncooperative?" ... Her only response was "You're being really annoying right now", but I kept talking and asking questions, then she starts to ignore me, and so I asked "You don't want to educate me ? You want to keep me stupid ? You enjoy the stupid ? You enjoy stupid drunk drivers ?". Then the cop who originally stopped me interrupts me and says "So why do you have condoms without spermicide, it's because you have sex with yourself." And the female officer laughed. I simply said I just buy whatevers cheapest, then he says if you weren't doing drugs you could afford the better condoms.<br>
<br>
 When the arresting officer was leaving the station, he comes up to me and says "okay, I'm going to go get more bad guys". And I said I'm just confused, did you want me to just admit to running the red light ? And he simply said "I just want to save the world." <br>
<br>
 While being fingerprinted, the female officer was pressing my hands down extra hard, because that's the only abuse she could do to me that I couldn't prove. Although she was using both her hands to press down, so maybe I could prove it.<br>
<br>
 While in the booking cell, the cop that arrested me was already gone, and the female officer from earlier and another black officer were talking to each other around the corner as they were observing me like a rat in a cage. The female officer comes over and says to me "1 more hour", and I look at her like okay, why you telling me this. Then she asks me if I have someone to pick me up, I said no. Then the black officer opens the door and calls me to the door. The female officer is standing next to him. He asks if I was okay, I said I'm fine. Then he said why you sweating man? and I said I don't know. Then for some reason the female officer says to the black cop "See". Then he asked why you here man? And I said it was a traffic stop and they did some blood tests. Then the two officers just stared at me for 10 seconds like I was going to perform a magic trick or something. Then the female officer looks at the black cop and I'm sure she was thinking like okay, now what do we do ? Then the black cop finally tells me and the other guy in the cell with me okay go get your shoes, then they transported all of us to the detention center where I stayed overnight.<br>
<br>
 Charged with driving under the influence of drugs, spent a night in jail, $700 to get my car back, blood tests came back weeks later and showed no drugs in my system. <br>
<br>
 I'm sure all those cops still think I had drugs in my system. Lost souls. I will pray for them.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5444">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    What Obama and the government should address is HOW these police departments are able to get their other high priced equipment and weaponry.<br>
Namely, the egregious abusive practice of police departments across this country with a process called asset forfeiture. A disgrace in so-called "law enforcement" that's allowed to exist and thrive that has everything to do with profit and little to do with justice.<br>
Where a police officer can pull you over and just take whatever money or valuables you possess without charging you with any crime whatsoever.<br>
Which USED to be unconstitutional and a violation of unreasonable searches and seizures.<br>
With them knowing that the people, having their property unjustifiably confiscated, face an incredible amount of time and expense to fight to get their property back.<br>
Which shouldn't have been taken from them in the first place.<br>
And IF, they can get it back at all. Which is a BIG if and FAR from a guarantee.<br>
THOUSANDS of people across this country have had their money, cars, houses, boats and you name it confiscated by police depts.with this HIGHLY profitable and corrupt practice that has added hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars that fund their police budgets.
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    I have never been to Russia but here in the US we always here that Russia and China are both police states. The police supposedly run and control everything. But with that said, I have been to China many times, first time when I was in recovery for cancer. My brother went with me on that trip and both of us agreed everything we had ever been told, had read or thought was wrong about China. The US is the POLICE state compared to China. In China I never had a fear of the Chinese police, the locals never feared the Chinese police. The Chinese police did not carry guns, tazers, any kind of shock sticks nor any kind of spray gas. I met a Chinese lady there in 2007 and today we are married. I have eat and drunk much liquor with police in China and there is no feeling of superiority from them as the police here in the US have. The police in China help you with tazis and getting around in areas you know nothing of. I am almost 65 and have lived in the US all my life. I do KNOW how the law is used and abused here now and for the past 50 years or so. As Americans we HAVE to do something about our country or we will become the devil we preached about for the past 50 years.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5570">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    I think body camera are a great idea, unfortunately I think they are going to benefit police officers more than citizens.  The police will be constantly aware that they are on, unruly, law-breaking, assaulting insects will not be.  The cameras are going to put an end to cops being unfairly accused of wrong-doing by thugs and others who think they should be able to do whatever whenever simply because they are black!  Bring it on!!  I think it is interesting that we aren't hearing more support of body cameras on police from the black communities - you would think that they would think it is the greatest thing in the world???  But of course they probably also realize that what it really means is that like in 98% of incidences like Ferguson where it is "he said, she said" the cameras are going to show black law-breakers in the wrong and not the police!  Whoopsie, interesting turn of perspective isn't it!!!!
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                        Places they have tried giving police body cameras have seen complaints against the police drop by around 70%.  Apparently just knowing that the cameras are on keeps the police in line.  But yes, it is also for the protection of the police from made up accusations and exaggerations.  There really is no rational argument against it beyond the general cost.  And given how much we already spend on police, this is just a minor cost that will help everyone involved by making rulings about interactions with police become based on actual evidence.
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                        TeaTrollPatrol: That's just exactly why the huge "racism" argument about Ferguson is just a lot of hooey.  A lot of blacks assume that whites don't get treated poorly by cops, as part of "white privilege." Nonsense.  Probably the biggest deterrent keeping me from choosing crime in my teen years was the certain knowledge/belief that I would probably be brutalized by cops and prison guards.<br>

BUT: the mayor and chief of police decide the allocation of police and that decision is made by the crime statistics.  A high crime area gets more cops and people who look, talk and act like criminals get more focus, and rightly so.  It's not racial profiling, it's criminal profiling.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5633">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                        Absolutely crazy that trying to do their job, all law enforcement officials will have to be video wired at all times. We also know that in any occupation you are dealing with other frail human beings that are not always perfect. Anyone with a lick of sense also knows, that for this reason bad lemons turn up in police uniforms and tailor-made suits and religious garb. I venture to say this however. Put body cameras on all police officials and considering what we have in the general public today, I don´t think much will change. That is, unless this rioting, lotting and other classes from petty to grand larceny and killing, start changing. Of course we could go one step farther and take away arms from law enforcement to pacify the lawless class. With the video cameras, and no guns, an every increasing number of dead policemen would have a undisputed record of how they met their fate. At this point there will not be many volunteers for law enforcement and we may need something else. An Executive order or better yet, Congressional legislation to start a procedure of drafting recruits to fill the needed slots. How does that sound on a non discrimination basis as to color, creed or religion?
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Something was lacking, for sure.  The National Guard was called out.  The local police was provided protective gear, and cars were burned anyway.  Businesses were destroyed anyway.  Something was lacking.  Maybe there are too many restrictions on what the Enforcers are allowed to do.  Good grief! The mother, father, step-father, step-mother, mother's boyfriend have behaved badly since this happened.  They claimed (on camera) that they wanted everyone to remain calm and peaceful.  They were "caught" on camera, using filthy language, yelling at policemen and reporters,  climbing on cars, yelling and encouraging destruction of the town.  They have fought with other family members over the selling of Michael Brown T-shirts.  (What were the proceeds to go?  To a charity?<br>
To a Michael Brown scolarship fund?  I doubt it)  <br>
A great deal of attention is being directed at improving the credibility of policemen.  What needs to be 'fixed'  here?<br>
How much change is going to be made in teaching people to accept responsibility?  To obey the law?  To choose right over wrong? To treat others with respect?<br>
What if the policeman had been black?  What if the rebellious, defiant person had been white?   <br>
Where are we directing our attention?  Why?<br>
Too many "leaders"  make statements regarding the destruction of the town, as "the anger is understandable."<br>
As long as this behavior continues,  Al Sharpton and Jesse Jackson have job security.  The pastors that spoke at Michael Brown's funeral were too understanding,  too tolerant,  of the actions in the community.  It's one thing to be concerned about the grieving family and friends. But, also, remind folks that changes in behavior have to happen in order for the situation to improve.<br>
Enough is enough.  The show of support from the five St. Louis Rams was wrong.  The family and friends of Michael Brown had simmering anger before August 9th.  This gave them an excuse to vent that anger.  They are enjoying the opportunity.  Sadly.
                    </p>

                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">

                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5754">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    It's fine for police to HAVE this equipment, it's the policies regarding WHEN and HOW they use it that needs serious review.<br>
A lot has contributed to the militarization of police, and it's not just the stuff they have.  The fact that the threats they face have become much more serious, deadly, and well equipped is part of it.  Also, the large numbers of combat veterans getting out of the army and looking to police work as a way to continue their public service has brought with it the military combat mentality.  Policing is not akin to soldiering.  Unfortunately, the mindsets, training, and tactics of too many agencies have been drifting in that direction.  I know.  I've been working in and with law enforcement and the military for nearly 20 years, and have been uncomfortable with the militaristic trends for many of them.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_5838">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Local police do NOT need to have these weapons, vehicles and combat clothing. That gear should be left to the Nation Guard troops of each state. Local police are NOT meant to be (nor ever should be) a militarized force.<br>
<br>
Seeing police geared up for an assault as if it were an invasion on foreign soil shocked me. I truly believe this kind of Shock-n-Awe tactics by police have no place on the streets of any city in America. If the situation calls for that level of force then it should be up to the Governors to call in the Guard Troops. A military level response should never be taken lightly and without a level of oversight that simply does not exist at the local level. <br>
<br>
Lets not fix the problem by training the police to be something they aren't suppose to be in the first place. This executive order does not go near far enough to stop the flow of military weapons into the hands of local police. I hope congress (as broken as they are) do something to stop AND recover the weapons that have already been distributed. Lets continue to train our police forces to "serve and protect".<br>
<br>
If we continue to allow the bar to be lowered on what is considered to be acceptable force in this country, be it from civil unrest or threats of foreign attacks, then one day we will wake up in a police state.  Local police are meant to be a part of the community. I don't ever want to see someone on my streets dressed in camouflage combat gear unless the Governor has declared a state of emergency or martial law. Is there a petition out there we can sign to stop this flow of military weapons into the hands of our local police?
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    It's a tragedy that this young man died.  All to often the race card is applied to situation and if one dares to say anything they are labeled a racist.  From the President on down only soft discussions are heard at realistically curbing the violence and talking about the core problems with solutions to the problem.<br>
  Now I don't believe that police officers go out to do their duty and are eager to kill anyone.  Now some police officers are corrupt and their should be reasonable oversight and more video cameras.  However when a corrupt police officer is found guilty the punishment usually minor and if it were someone else we would be sitting in jail awaiting a trail or plea bargain!  This should outrage all American's  We are all protected by theory under the constitution of Equal Protection under the Law.  When citizen's are incarcerated without reasonable bond relating to their offense or judged in a circus like media frenzy this idea and human right is ignored.<br>
 Another problem that isn't discussed enough in public by our leaders is the emotionally charged  acts of violence by our young people and the quest to decrease.  Everyday brothers are killing brothers regardless of race.  Every night no matter where you live people are killing one another in the streets.  Too often they are very young, don't have enough parental supervision, come from broken homes, drugs or other horrors from the streets.<br>
  The solution to this problem is complex but is hardly spoken.  More open discussions of family values, the absence of a father figure in the home, gangs, drugs, unemployment and many others.  By not addressing the causative factors and no will to change we are still going to see our young people die in the streets by police officers but more likely than one another senselessly.<br>
  It is sad that every time a person of race is killed the race card has to be played by our so called leaders who are really in it for the moment.  Until we can as a society talk about this in an  earnest dialogue the senseless violence will continue.  My prayers are with the Brown family.<br>
  Another short note, when the police don't have the tools to fight crime and unrest.  Guess who they will have to call....the military.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_6257">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    A nation can survive its fools, and even the ambitious. But it cannot survive treason from within. An enemy at the gates is less formidable, for he is known and carries his banner openly. But the traitor moves amongst those within the gate freely, his sly whispers rustling through all the alleys, heard in the very halls of government itself. For the traitor appears not a traitor; he speaks in accents familiar to his victims, and he wears their face and their arguments, he appeals to the baseness that lies deep in the hearts of all men. He rots the soul of a nation, he works secretly and unknown in the night to undermine the pillars of the city, he infects the body politic so that it can no longer resist. A murderer is less to fear.” By: Marcus Tullius Cicero
                    </p>

                    Stay The Course<br>
<br>
“Stay The Course,” is this the instructions King Obama will be giving his loyal subjects and followers ? Rather than being a uniter, he is driving a wedge between the black and white communities with his racial rhetoric. He would be better served if he would call for a halt to these public demonstrations and civil disobedience rather than fanning the flames oif racism along with his followers with Holder, Sharpton, Jackson, et al. He should also get with the Brown family to instruct them regarding the just and proper ways to voice their disapproval of what they believe is an injustice. Violence and riots is not the answer<br>
The Grand Jury has weighed all the evidence and listened to all the testimony and has arrived at their answer for all to see and hear. If you do not agree with the answer. It is your responsibility toi reply legally and without violence.<br>
I will refer you to the OJ Simpson trial which many people did not agree with, but nobody resorted to riots, burning or looting.

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1417502046200_6402">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Most of these heavily plated vehicular "weapons" are defensive in nature.  The armored personnel carriers became popular with cops after the school shootings and the California bank shootout (where the officers had to borrow an armored car from the bank to rescue people being shot).  In the event your kid is stuck in a school with a guy shooting an automatic weapon, cops cant just drive up to the front door in a police car and get them out.  They need something to protect them and the people they are trying to get to safety.  I have no problem with them having these vehicles for these types of emergencies, but they dont need to be mounting 50 cal machine guns to the top of them..which i rally dont think many police agencies do anyway.
                    </p>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Seems to me that all the vehicles and equipment could easily be accounted for if the issuing agencies would use the same system the military does. Hand Receipts. Communist countries have this type of system in place. Obama has no business getting into criminal investigation or any other part of police work. If the police require more training, that should be up to their individual state. If we allow the President to control the police, and the military, people stop controlling the country and are completely at the mercy of the ruler, namely Obama, which is exactly what he wants.

        <div class="comment-container clearfix   ">
            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="https://socialprofiles.zenfs.com/images/77ed7efaf01bc3127b8eb3a39cb0a4c6_48.jpeg" title="Jeremiah" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="DBIFXUGD6N2D6ZCYW2DYGLYDYY">Jeremiah</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">11 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">0</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">1</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                        While I agree with your position about with MB and his actions, suspected and known, I feel like the militarization that the resulting protests brought to light needs to be addressed. When you look at reports that show SWAT responses to very minor infractions or even serving warrants, there is something wrong with the process. The police exist to keep the peace and enforce the law. While they need to protect themselves, I agree that they should, their arrival in armored vehicles wearing SWAT/riot gear with fully automatic weapons held in an aggressive manner will only serve to add fuel to the fire, especially when the police force is seen by many in the crowd as the abuser, rightly or wrongly. <br>
<br>
Military training (as referenced in the article) dictates that you don't point a gun at another human unless your intention is to shoot them. The police need to be equipped to respond in kind and with authority but to a protest, their response was over the top aggressive and speaks to a very cavalier attitude and insular power structure that is often above reproach even from elected officials. <br>
<br>
When you have a 23k person town in New Hampshire getting a Bearcat APC and what appeared to be multiple snipers standing watch over a fall festival (this year a small riot broke out on one street) then you have to question the response.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>
            </div>

                    <p class="comment-content">
